--- title: "1.2 — What Exactly is Economics? — Class Content" execute: freeze: auto --- ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.callout-note appearance=minimal} # Meeting Dates *Thursday, August 25, 2022* ::: ## Overview Today we discuss some common themes we will encounter this semester, and take a broad philosophical approach to what economics is and how it has developed. ## Readings ### Required Readings NONE ### Recommended Readings This week we will be covering elements of: - Ch.1 (Introduction) in Landreth and Colander - Preface & Ch.17 (Methodological Postscript) in Blaug 1996 Other helpful readings: - [ Buchanan, 1964, “What Should Economists Do?”](/files/readings/Buchanan-1964.pdf) - [ Blaug, 1975, "Kuhn versus Lakatos, or paradigms versus research programmes in the history of economics"](/files/readings/Blaug-1975.pdf) - [ McCloskey, 1998, *The Rhetoric of Economics* pp.20-28](/files/readings/McCloskey-1998.pdf) The following Wikipedia entries can also provide more background on the philosophy of science (broadly in order): - [ Philosophy of Science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy_of_science) - [ Positivism](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Positivism) - [ Logical Positivism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logical_positivism) - [ Karl Popper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karl_Popper) - [ Thomas Kuhn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Kuhn) - [ Imre Lakatos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imre_Lakatos) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imre_Lakatos - [ Lionel Robbins on Economics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/An_Essay_on_the_Nature_and_Significance_of_Economic_Science) - [ Milton Friedman on Positivist Methodology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Essays_in_Positive_Economics) ## Slides Below, you can find the slides in two formats. Clicking the image will bring you to the html version of the slides in a new tab. The lower button will allow you to download a PDF version of the slides. ::: callout-tip You can type h to see a special list of viewing options, and type o for an outline view of all the slides. ::: I suggest printing the slides beforehand and using them to take additional notes in class (*not everything* is in the slides)!
